content: <collection xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/MARC21/slim"> <record>   <controlfield tag="001">10573</controlfield>   <controlfield tag="005">20140809003825.0</controlfield>   <datafield tag="520" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a"><p>We present a sensitive search for&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;<em>W</em>3 (12 &mu;m) and&nbsp;<em>W</em>4 (22 &mu;m) excesses from warm optically thin dust around&nbsp;<em>Hipparcos</em>&nbsp;main sequence stars within 75 pc from the Sun. We use contemporaneously measured photometry from&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>, remove sources of contamination, and derive and apply corrections to saturated fluxes to attain optimal sensitivity to &gt;10 &mu;m excesses. We use data from the&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;All-Sky Survey Catalog rather than the AllWISE release because we find that its saturated photometry is better behaved, allowing us to detect small excesses even around saturated stars in&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>. Our new discoveries increase by 45% the number of stars with warm dusty excesses and expand the number of known debris disks (with excess at any wavelength) within 75 pc by 29%. We identify 220&nbsp;<em>Hipparcos</em>&nbsp;debris disk host stars, 108 of which are new detections at any wavelength. We present the first measurement of a 12&nbsp;&mu;m and/or 22&nbsp;&mu;m excess for 10 stars with previously known cold (50-100 K) disks. We also find five new stars with small but significant&nbsp;<em>W</em>3 excesses, adding to the small population of known exozodi, and we detect evidence for a&nbsp;<em>W</em>2 excess around HIP&nbsp;96562 (F2V), indicative of tenuous hot (780 K) dust. As a result of our&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;study, the number of debris disks with known 10-30&nbsp;&mu;m excesses within 75 pc (379) has now surpassed the number of disks with known &gt;30 &mu;m excesses (289, with 171 in common), even if the latter have been found to have a higher occurrence rate in unbiased samples.</p></subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="540" ind1=" " ind2=" ">
